Award.AwardTitle: PFI-TT: Development of a Software-Reconfigurable, Ultrafast Spectroscopic Microscope
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is the development of a versatile tool for optically characterizing and imaging a broad range of industrially relevant materials including chemicals, biological systems, pigments and semiconductors. The characterization will be achieved using a suite of ultrafast light-based (spectroscopic) methods. Switching between spectroscopic methods will be realized by reconfiguration of the software alone, no changes to the hardware will be necessary. Optical methods have the advantage of being non-contact and potentially can be implemented in a remote/stand-off configuration, depending on the needs of the specific application. Broadening the range of target materials will increase the societal impact of this methodology by increasing the scope of industries to which the method and tool are applicable.<br/><br/>The proposed project is based on demonstrating a broader range of scientific applications that a single-beam, optical, nonlinear spectrometer can access and extending the modalities of the spectrometer as well as implementing imaging capabilities. The spectrometer has been applied to several semiconductor samples and devices. If the nonlinear spectrometer, which is uniquely capable of being integrated with a microscope, is demonstrated for use with chemical and biological systems, the technology may have impact on those scientific communities as well as related industries. Because the nonlinear interaction of light with chemical and biological systems is much weaker than in semiconductors, this demonstration is high risk and high reward.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project was the development of a versatile tool for optically characterizing and imaging a broad range of industrially relevant materials including chemicals, biological systems, pigments and semiconductors. The characterization was achieved using a suite of ultrafast light-based (spectroscopic) methods. Switching between spectroscopic methods was realized by reconfiguration of the software alone, no changes to the hardware was necessary. Optical methods have the advantage of being non-contact and potentially can be implemented in a remote/stand-off configuration, depending on the needs of the specific application. Broadening the range of target materials increases the societal impact of this methodology by increasing the scope of industries to which the method and tool are applicable.

The  project was based on demonstrating a broader range of scientific applications that a single-beam, optical, nonlinear spectrometer can access and extending the modalities of the spectrometer as well as implementing imaging capabilities. The spectrometer had been applied to several semiconductor samples and devices.

The intellectual merit was the performance of spectroscopic imaging  on transition metal dichalcogenide (TMD) samples. These materials are similar to graphene in that they are layered and single monolayers can be realized through exfoliation (the so-called "scotch-tape method"). However they differ from graphene in that they are semiconductors, thus are potential candidates for a wider range of technological applications. Moreover, at the single monolayer limit, they show remarkably strong interaction with light. However, the exfoliation techniques are less sophisticated, so the fabrication process results in much greater spatial inhomogeneity. This inhomogeneity can be manifest in relatively simple ways, such as changes in the color of light that they absorb, or in more subtle ways that can only be accessed using sophisticated methods. Specifically, we looked at the how the coupling between electronic states in two adjacent layers varied with spatial position.

While useful, this initial work involved taking a spectrum in two frequency dimensions at every spatial point, which was prohibitively time consuming. Thus we explored faster methods and showed that they also provided important information, Namely, we demonstrated producing images based on just the strength of the nonlinear signal due the mixiing of the incident pulses (known at the four-wave-mixing signal), the homogeneous linewidth at a fixed frequency and the energy relaxation. We demonstated that all of these can be aquired rapidly, with image acquisition times on the order of one minute. We demonstrated these modalities on several different TMD samples, including exfoliated flakes and samples grown by chemical vapor deposition.

These results demonstrate a general purpose nonlnear spectroscopic microscope using laser scanning for image acquisition with multiple spectroscopic modalities that can be selected by simple reconfiguraiton of the software in the floating-point gate array processor. The methods are applicable to a broad range of materials, beyond the TMD samples used here, including chemical and biological materials.
